title: The Pragmatic Engineer Test
author: Gergely Orosz
fullText: This is the full text of the Pragmatic Engineer Test article. It outlines a checklist for engineers to evaluate the health and practices of a potential employer's engineering team. Key areas include code quality, testing culture, CI/CD, on-call practices, and career development. The test serves as a framework for asking insightful questions during interviews to gauge the engineering maturity of a company. It suggests that companies with strong engineering cultures will have positive answers to most of the checklist items, such as having a documented architectural approach, a clear testing strategy, and a fair and sustainable on-call rotation. The article emphasizes that no company is perfect, but the answers to these questions reveal a company's priorities and its commitment to engineering excellence. It provides a list of questions that senior engineers should ask, such as 'What is the on-call situation like?' and 'How does the promotion process work?'. Ultimately, the test is a tool for empowerment, helping engineers make informed decisions about where they choose to work.

title: The T-Shaped Person: Building a Broader Skill Set
author: J. Jabry
fullText: This article explains the concept of a 'T-shaped' professional. The vertical bar of the 'T' represents the depth of skills and expertise in a single field, while the horizontal bar represents the ability to collaborate across disciplines with experts in other areas and to apply knowledge in areas of expertise other than one's own. The author argues that building a T-shaped skill set is crucial for effective teamwork and innovation in modern organizations. It allows for better communication and collaboration between different specialists, such as designers, engineers, and product managers. The article provides tips on how to become more T-shaped, such as seeking out cross-functional projects, learning the basics of adjacent disciplines, and actively practicing empathy to understand the perspectives of colleagues from different backgrounds. The ultimate goal is to foster a team of individuals who are not only deep experts but also effective collaborators, leading to more creative and successful outcomes.

title: Giving and Receiving Feedback Effectively
author: Center for Creative Leadership
fullText: This article details best practices for both giving and receiving feedback in a professional setting. For giving feedback, it emphasizes the importance of being specific, objective, and timely. It introduces frameworks like the Situation-Behavior-Impact (SBI) model to structure conversations constructively. The goal is to focus on the behavior and its impact, rather than making personal judgments. For receiving feedback, the article stresses the importance of listening actively, asking clarifying questions, and showing appreciation, even if the feedback is difficult to hear. It advises against becoming defensive and instead encourages a mindset of curiosity and a commitment to growth. The article concludes that a healthy feedback culture is a cornerstone of high-performing teams, as it fosters trust, accelerates learning, and drives continuous improvement for both individuals and the organization as a whole.

title: AI Agents, Clearly Explained
author: Wade Foster (Zapier)
fullText: Zapier CEO Wade Foster argues that most people asking for 'AI agents' actually want 'agentic workflows.' He suggests that fully autonomous agents are not yet reliable for complex tasks, and the most practical approach today is a middle ground that combines deterministic steps with targeted AI interventions. The best 'agents' are small, focused workflows that do one specific task exceptionally well. Foster uses his own email triage system as an example: an agentic workflow that categorizes over 100 daily emails into a manageable list of 10, sorting them into buckets like 'action required,' 'EA should handle,' or 'FYI only.' This laser-focused approach provides immediate, reliable value, which is more effective than trying to build a single, all-knowing agent. The key takeaway is to start with well-defined, single-purpose workflows to build trust and utility, rather than chasing the hype of fully autonomous systems.

title: The 8 Evaluation Checks Smart AI Teams Never Skip
author: Dhaval Bhatt
fullText: This article argues that the reliability of AI products depends on structured evaluations, not just 'vibes' or gut checks. It outlines eight critical checks that serious AI teams use to pressure-test their systems before production. 1. **Redundancy Checks:** Catching repetitive, low-value phrases. 2. **Compression Pressure:** Ensuring summaries are concise and fluff-free. 3. **Factual Drift:** Verifying outputs against source data to catch subtle inaccuracies. 4. **Ordering Logic:** Validating that ranked lists are logically sorted, not random. 5. **Tone Alignment:** Ensuring the AI's communication style matches the intended audience. 6. **Structural Consistency:** Checking for consistent formatting and patterns across many outputs. 7. **Cost-to-Value Ratio:** Evaluating if the output quality justifies the token cost. 8. **Latency vs. Utility:** Ensuring the response time is within the user's 'patience threshold.' The core message is that building dependable AI requires creating real evaluation scaffolding, not just prompting and hoping for the best.

title: Introducing Company Knowledge for ChatGPT Enterprise
author: OpenAI
fullText: OpenAI announced 'company knowledge,' a new feature for ChatGPT Enterprise that allows businesses to securely connect their internal data sources. This feature enables ChatGPT to provide answers grounded in a company's specific context, from internal wikis in Confluence to documents in SharePoint and Google Drive. The core of this feature is a secure, private Retrieval-Augmented Generation (RAG) system. This ensures that employees can get relevant, accurate answers based on their organization's unique data, processes, and terminology. The primary benefits are increased productivity, faster onboarding for new hires, and ensuring AI-generated content is contextually appropriate. OpenAI emphasizes that this is built with enterprise-grade security and privacy, meaning a company's data is not used for training public models. This feature represents a major step in making AI a practical, trusted tool for everyday work within large organizations by directly and securely integrating their proprietary knowledge.

title: How AI Is Impacting Engineering Leadership
author: Gregor Ojstersek
fullText: This article explores the significant, and often negative, impact of AI on engineering leadership and team morale. A key statistic from a LeadDev report reveals that 51% of engineering leaders view AI's impact on the industry negatively. This sentiment is driven by several factors. First, sensationalistic predictions from public figures about AI replacing engineers create fear and demotivation. Second, company leaders experience FOMO, leading them to enforce top-down AI adoption with unrealistic expectations, such as 100x productivity gains, without understanding the complexity. This pressure trickles down, forcing engineering teams to operate within these unrealistic constraints. The article argues that the solution for leaders is to own the AI strategy, not just react to it. This involves educating themselves, managing expectations, running small, measured experiments, and focusing on culture. For engineering leaders, AI product strategy is becoming the new essential leadership skill. They must understand the 'what, when, why, and how' to lead the ecosystem, as engineering roles become more blurred and product-mindedness becomes a requirement, not a nice-to-have.

title: How to Create Engineering Handbooks
author: Hybrid Hacker
fullText: This article outlines the importance and structure of creating an engineering handbook. An engineering handbook serves as a single source of truth for a company's engineering practices, culture, and processes. It's an essential tool for scaling teams, streamlining onboarding, and ensuring consistency. The author suggests that a good handbook should be a living document, continuously updated by the team. Key sections to include are the company's mission and values, team structure and roles, communication guidelines (e.g., how to use Slack, email, and meetings), technical principles (e.g., coding standards, architectural patterns), and processes for key workflows like code reviews, incident response, and project management. The article argues that investing time in a comprehensive handbook pays massive dividends by reducing ambiguity, empowering engineers to make autonomous decisions, and creating a more transparent and efficient engineering culture. A handbook is the foundation upon which scalable, high-performing teams are built.

title: AI Product Strategy for Engineering Leaders
author: Gregor Ojstersek and Miqdad Jaffer
fullText: This article asserts that in the age of AI, engineering leaders must own the AI product strategy, not just execute on a roadmap handed to them. Because AI systems are probabilistic and complex, traditional product specs are insufficient. Engineers are uniquely positioned to understand the crucial trade-offs between cost, latency, model choice, RAG vs. fine-tuning, and data feedback loops. These are no longer implementation details; they are core strategic decisions that define the product's defensibility and performance. The article argues that 'Engineering Strategy IS AI Product Strategy.' It introduces a framework for thinking about this new reality, which includes three non-negotiable dimensions: 1. **Probabilistic Outputs:** Designing for variability and trust. 2. **Compounding Loops:** Building feedback mechanisms so the product gets smarter with use. 3. **Economic Alignment:** Managing inference costs and model mixing to ensure profitability at scale. The key takeaway for CTOs and engineering leaders is to take a seat at the strategy table and develop the skills to answer not just the 'how,' but the 'what, when, and why' of building AI products.

title: How to Use AI to Help With Planning Engineering Projects
author: Gregor Ojstersek and Steven Levey
fullText: This article provides a deep dive into 'Context Engineering' as a method for planning complex engineering projects with AI. It argues that providing rich, structured context is the key to getting high-quality, strategic outputs from LLMs. The authors provide a detailed, step-by-step guide for creating a master prompt that includes multiple data sources: current business context (constraints, deadlines), team structure (skills, availability), sprint backlog data from Jira, resource allocation matrices, historical performance metrics, and recent stakeholder feedback. The article presents a complete example prompt following the C.R.A.F.T.E.D. framework, designed for an Engineering Manager to get AI-driven recommendations on action items, resource allocation, and risk mitigation. The core philosophy is to treat 'prompts as code'—they should be version-controlled, shareable, testable, and dynamically populated with data from source systems. This approach moves beyond simple prompting to a more reliable, engineering-driven discipline.

title: How to Use AI to Help With Software Engineering Tasks
author: Gregor Ojstersek and Steven Levey
fullText: This article introduces the C.R.A.F.T.E.D. prompt framework, a structured approach to help software engineers save time on common tasks. The framework is an acronym that guides users to provide comprehensive context to the AI: Context, Role, Action, Format, Tone, Examples, and Definition of Done. By following this structure, engineers can get more reliable and accurate responses from LLMs for tasks like writing code, generating documentation, or refactoring. The authors argue that 'Context Engineering' is a crucial skill. The article provides a detailed example of a complete prompt for a project planning scenario, demonstrating how to fill each section of the C.R.A.F.T.E.D. framework with rich, specific information. The key takeaway is that treating prompts with the same discipline as code—by engineering the context—leads to dramatically better results and moves AI from a novelty to a reliable engineering tool.

title: How to Use AI to Increase Software Development Productivity
author: Gregor Ojstersek
fullText: This article explores practical ways engineering leaders can use AI to boost their team's productivity. It moves beyond the hype and focuses on tangible applications. The author suggests that the biggest gains come from using AI to automate or accelerate non-coding tasks that consume a significant portion of a developer's day, such as writing documentation, summarizing meetings, and planning projects. The article provides specific examples, like using an AI to analyze a project backlog and suggest prioritization based on business goals and dependencies. It also emphasizes the importance of measuring the impact of AI tools, not just assuming they are effective. The core message is that AI's true value isn't just in writing code faster, but in freeing up engineers' cognitive load so they can focus on higher-level problem-solving and innovation. For leaders, the goal is to strategically introduce AI to remove friction and amplify their team's creative potential.

title: How to Use AI to Be a Great Engineering Leader
author: Gregor Ojstersek
fullText: This article outlines how engineering leaders can leverage AI to become more effective in their roles. It argues that AI is a 'force multiplier' for leadership, capable of handling administrative tasks and providing data-driven insights. The author provides several concrete use cases for managers: preparing for 1-on-1 meetings by having an AI summarize a direct report's recent work and suggest talking points; drafting job descriptions and interview questions to streamline hiring; and creating performance review summaries based on peer feedback and project outcomes. The article also touches on more strategic uses, such as using an AI to analyze team communication patterns in public Slack channels to gauge morale or identify knowledge silos. The central theme is that by delegating repetitive and data-synthesis tasks to AI, engineering leaders can free up their time to focus on the uniquely human aspects of their job: mentoring, coaching, setting vision, and building culture.

title: How to Use AI to Improve Teamwork in Engineering Teams
author: Gregor Ojstersek and Henry Poydar
fullText: This article explores how AI can be used to enhance, rather than replace, teamwork in engineering organizations. The authors suggest that AI can act as a neutral facilitator and communication aid, helping to bridge gaps and improve collaboration. They propose several practical applications. First, using AI to generate structured agendas for meetings and summarize the key decisions and action items afterward, ensuring everyone is aligned. Second, using AI as a 'translator' to help engineers communicate complex technical topics to non-technical stakeholders in a clear and concise way. Third, using an AI to facilitate blameless post-mortems by creating an objective timeline of events and guiding the team through a structured root cause analysis. The underlying principle is that AI can handle the logistical and administrative aspects of collaboration, allowing team members to focus on the creative and strategic parts of working together, leading to better outcomes and stronger team cohesion.
